issue.title: [DOC] Classification notebook clean-up, added new pipelines

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR cleans up the classification notebook a bit and adds new features added since 0.8.0.

Clean-up:

* moving imports to sections and cells to avoid huge initial import and allow easier copy-pasting of self-contained code blocks
* some formulations clarified

New features now covered:

* loading of data in arbitrary, and most common panel formats `pd-multiindex` and `nested_univ`, explained
* `numpyflat` aka `numpy2d` type is kept and presented
* classifiers accepting arbitrary input formats, including the above
* `make_pipeline` and dunder operators for constructing TSC classifier pipelines

body:
from slack:

I see 2 major options and one family of minor ones

* option A: 2D numpy is always numpyflat (Panel)
* option B: 2D numpy is always numpy2D  (Series)
* option C: depends on scitype, and then you need to say for classifiers, transformers, and forecasters what it should be

I think at least temporary, we need to have option C with numpyflat for classifiers and numpy2D for forecasters, everything else is a deprecation nightmare

transformers had numpy2D as intention but a bug with anything numpy
So panel transformers should assume rows are cases imo, anything else is counter intuitive. Series transformers assume a single multivariate series
Can you not just tag the internal data type meaning?

> Can you not just tag the internal data type meaning?

That wouldn't work with transformers, where it has to be either or.

> So panel transformers should assume rows are cases imo, anything else is counter intuitive. Series transformers assume a single multivariate series

There is no such thing anymore as panel/series transformers - all transformers accept series and panel data now, and the default behaviour to switch between the two is "iterate over series" (if panel) or "interpret as one-series panel" (if series).

rename.from: [ENH] type inference default clash between transformers and classifiers
rename.to: [ENH] type inference default clash between transformers and classifiers in case of 2D numpy input

rename.from: [ENH] type inference default clash between transformers and classifiers in case of 2D numpy input
rename.to: [ENH] type convention clash between transformers and classifiers in case of 2D numpy input

body:
current, broken behaviour of transformers: if given 2D numpy array of shape (m, n), interpret this as m instances, n variables, 1 time point - which is why it produces format compatible with `numpyflat`, but is garbage, content-wise

pandas plain, of same shape, is interpreted correctly, as 1 series with n variables and m time points.

pandas nested, of same shape, is also fine, as m instances with n variables.

> > So panel transformers should assume rows are cases imo, anything else is counter intuitive. Series transformers assume a single multivariate series
> 
> There is no such thing anymore as panel/series transformers - all transformers accept series and panel data now, and the default behaviour to switch between the two is "iterate over series" (if panel) or "interpret as one-series panel" (if series).

well I was not party to that, we always used to have panel and series transformers, which seemed sensible to me. I would have been against the change if I had time to form an opinion, this being one use case why.  I thought you had reassured me I could throughput 2D numpy, so I left transformers well alone, but perhaps that is only 3D numpy. I have enough to do on distances, classification, clustering and regression, transformers is not my current priority. I dont want you to change my classification notebook though

>  I thought you had reassured me I could throughput 2D numpy

That's for classifiers only.

What will work with 2D numpy as you intend:

* any classifier in sktime
* including a `ClassifierPipeline` with any transformer and any classifier in it
* including pipelines constructed with dunder methods `*`

The one case that doesn't work is using `sklearn` (not sktime) pipelines with `sktime` transformers if you are passing panel data.
Or, transformers in isolation.

> I dont want you to change my classification notebook though

That's why I made some changes to help.

Besides the 2D/3D numpy thing, I think there are also a few other useful additions there.

issue.title: [BUG] Handling of numpy2d in transformer Interface differs significantly from time series classification/clustering/regression user expectations

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
update (@fkiraly's summary of discussion, point 14-10-2022):

see discussion below. The reported behaviour is not a bug, but a frustrated user expectation.

This stems from how 2D numpy arrays are interpreted in `sktime` transformers and forecasters, an (m, n) array is interpreted as a single time series with m time points and n variables - let's call this convention A.

@patrickzib and @TonyBagnall think this is an unnatural way to interpret 2D numpy arrays, and would rather like an (m, n) array to be interpreted as m univariate time series of equal length (number time stamps) n - let's call this convention B.

This opinion agrees with the way in which @haskarb's user expectation was frustrated.

Related issue: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/2640
relation is: classifier interpret 2D numpy arrays as per convention B. Everywhere else, convention A is applied.
Issue #2640 is about the convention clash between classifiers and everywhere else.

---

**Describe the bug**
I'm performing MiniRocket tranformation on a small dataset. However there seems to be big difference in runtime.
Original repo [here](https://github.com/angus924/minirocket).


<!--
A clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->
![Screenshot 2022-09-29 at 12 29 22](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20501023/193008290-660fd8e5-b475-40cc-92a4-eb42654e8cbc.png)

From Sktime
![Screenshot 2022-09-29 at 12 29 54](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20501023/193008378-e6562735-5b34-4b31-abff-5971dfb23358.png)


**To Reproduce**


<!--
Add a Minimal, Complete, and Verifiable example (for more details, see e.g. https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve

If the code is too long, feel free to put it in a public gist and link it in the issue: https://gist.github.com
-->

```python
%%time
#original code from Angus's repo
train = np.random.rand(100,2000).astype('float32')

parameters = minirocket.fit(train)
X_training_transform = minirocket.transform(train, parameters)
```
```python
%%time
#MiniRocket from sktime
minirocket = MiniRocket()
parameters = minirocket.fit(train)

ts_transform = minirocket.transform(train)

```

**Expected behavior**
There shouldn't be so much difference in runtime. As I scale up the number of time-series, and length, this difference will become huge.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.
-->

**Additional context**
<!--
Add any other context about the problem here.
-->

**Versions**
<details>

<!--
Please run the following code snippet and paste the output here:
 
from sktime import show_versions; show_versions()
-->

</details>

<!-- Thanks for contributing! -->
